title: Water Purification Chemistry
scenario: A city's water supply is contaminated with dissolved lead (Pb²⁺), bacteria, and organic pollutants. The water authority must design a multi-stage purification system.
content:
Water purification applies multiple chemistry concepts: coagulation (adding Al₂(SO₄)₃ causes suspended particles to aggregate), filtration (physical separation), chlorination (Cl₂ kills bacteria via oxidation), and activated carbon adsorption (removes organic contaminants). Lead removal requires precipitation: adding Na₂SO₄ precipitates PbSO₄ (Ksp = 2.53 × 10⁻⁸).

Each stage demonstrates different chemical principles: ionic reactions, redox chemistry, and solubility equilibria all work together in a real-world system protecting public health.
guided_questions: What type of reaction is chlorination of water, and why does it kill bacteria?
Why does adding aluminium sulphate cause suspended particles to clump together?
Calculate the maximum [Pb²⁺] in water if [SO₄²⁻] = 0.01 mol/L and Ksp(PbSO₄) = 2.53 × 10⁻⁸.
what_you_learned: Water treatment integrates ionic reactions, precipitation equilibria, redox chemistry, and physical separation — demonstrating how chemistry protects public health at scale.
